headline: Chip Industry Shares Fall After US House Panel Slams China Sales
summary: Applied Materials, ASML, Tokyo Electron Ltd., KLA Corp. and Lam Research Corp. “made sizable returns selling equipment to Chinese state-owned and military-linked companies,” the House China panel said on Tuesday, citing the companies’ sales data.  There is no claim that any tool maker has violated US, Dutch or Japanese law.

headline: China gets around U.S. chip export rules, lawmakers warn
summary: Foreign chip makers sold to Chinese firms that U.S. firms were banned from supplying, lawmakers said, hindering efforts to curb Beijing’s progress

headline: S&P Futures Tick Higher Ahead of FOMC Meeting Minutes
summary: December S&P 500 E-Mini futures (ESZ25) are trending up +0.15% this morning, signaling a partial rebound from yesterday’s losses, while investors await the Federal Reserve’s September meeting minutes and remarks from central bank officials.

headline: How Does Applied Materials Stack Up After Nvidia Deal Fuels Semis Rally?
summary: If you’re eyeing Applied Materials and wondering whether it still has room to run, you’re in good company. The stock has been on a strong trajectory, leaving investors curious about whether now is the time to buy, hold, or look elsewhere. Over just the last week, the share price logged a 3.3% bump, capping off a remarkable 30.0% surge in the last month alone. Year to date, Applied Materials is up almost 29.1%, underscoring strong momentum rooted in its pivotal role within the semiconductor...

headline: US lawmakers call for broader bans on chipmaking tool sales to China
summary: SAN FRANCISCO (Reuters) -U.S. lawmakers are calling for broader bans on chipmaking equipment to China after a bipartisan investigation found that  Chinese chipmakers had purchased $38 billion of sophisticated gear last year.  Inconsistencies in rules issued by the United States, Japan and the Netherlands have led to non-U.S. chip equipment manufacturers selling to some Chinese firms that U.S. companies could not, according to a report published on Tuesday by the U.S. House of Representatives Select Committee on China.  That accounted for nearly 39% of the aggregate sales of Applied Materials, Lam Research, KLA, ASML and Tokyo Electron, the report found.
